/* This module defines standard operations that are always available.

   Some types and operations are required to be defined for the compiler
   to work correctly (i.e. types like `:int` or `:list`)
*/
public module core

infixr 80  (^)
infixl 70  (*), (%), (/), cdiv, cmod
infixl 60  (+), (-)
infix  40  (!=), (==), (<=), (>=), (<), (>) 
infixr 30  (&&)
infixr 20  (||)

// prefix     (!), (-) 

extern include {
  cs file "core-inline.cs"
  js file "core-inline.js"
}

extern include {
  js file "core-string-inline.js"
}

extern include {
  js file "core-console-inline.js"
}

extern include {
  js file "core-handlers-inline.js"
}

extern include {
  js file "contrib/biginteger.js"
}


// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Core types
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// An arbitrary precision signed integer.
type intstd/core/int: V

// A string is a sequence of unicode character points (`char`).
// The encoding of a string is internal and there
// is no constant-time indexing of characters in a string. 
// Use the `:sslice` type for efficient matching and retrieving
// sub-strings from string.\
// See also the [``std/text/string``](std_text_string.html) module.
type stringstd/core/string: V

// A 64-bit IEEE 754 floating point value
type doublestd/core/double: V

// An any type. Used for extern calls
type anystd/core/any: V

// A unicode character. 
// Characters are unicode _codepoint_\/s.
// This is different from a unicode _grapheme_ which represents a single displayed
// symbol and can consists of multiple codepoints due to combining characters and marks.
// (see also the [``std/text/unicode``](std_text_unicode.html) module.)
type charstd/core/char: V


// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Core effects
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// The _total_ effect represents the absence of any effect.
type <std/core/(<>): E> :: E

// The effect constructor extends an effect with another effect.
type <std/core/(<|>): (X, E) -> E|> :: (X,E) -> E

// The exception effect: a partial function may raise an exception.
type exnstd/core/exn: X :: X

// The divergence effect: a divergent function may not terminate.
type divstd/core/div: X :: X

// NonDeterminism: a nonDeterministic function may return varying
// results even when called with the same input values.
type ndetstd/core/ndet: X :: X

// The alloc effect signifies a function may allocate in a heap `:h`
type allocstd/core/alloc: H -> X :: H -> X

// The read effect: signifies that a function may read from from heap `:h`.
type readstd/core/read: H -> X :: H -> X

// The write effect: signifies that a function may write to heap `:h`.
type writestd/core/write: H -> X :: H -> X

// The console effect signifies that a function may read or write to the console.
type consolestd/core/console: X :: X

// An alias for the empty effect.
alias totalstd/core/total: E = <std/core/(<>): E>

// An alias for pure effects: a pure function always returns the same result
// when called with the same arguments but may not terminate or raise an exception.
alias purestd/core/pure: E = <std/core/(<>): Eexnstd/core/exn: X,divstd/core/div: X>

// Stateful funs can manipulate heap `:h` using allocations, reads and writes.
alias ststd/core/st: H -> E<hh: H> = <std/core/(<>): Ereadstd/core/read: H -> X<hh: H>, writestd/core/write: H -> X<hh: H>, allocstd/core/alloc: H -> X<hh: H>>

// The `:global` heap is a special heap constant to denote the global shared heap
type globalstd/core/global: H :: H

// The `:net` effect signifies a function may access the network
type netstd/core/net: X :: X

// The `:file` effect signifies a function may access the file system
type filestd/core/file: X :: X

// The `:ui` effect signifies a function may access the graphics system
type uistd/core/ui: X :: X

// The `:blocking` effect signifies that a function may block
type blockingstd/core/blocking: X :: X

// The `:io` effect is used for funs that perform arbitrary I/O operations.
alias iostd/core/io: E = <std/core/(<>): Eexnstd/core/exn: X,divstd/core/div: X,ndetstd/core/ndet: X,consolestd/core/console: X,netstd/core/net: X,filestd/core/file: X,uistd/core/ui: X,ststd/core/st: H -> E<globalstd/core/global: H>>

// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Injection
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// Add the divergent effect to a function effect.
extern inline inject-divstd/core/inject-div: forall<a,e> (() -> e a) -> (() -> <div|e> a) : forall<aa: V,ee: E> (() -> ee: E aa: V) -> ((std/core/(<>): E) -> <divstd/core/div: X|std/core/(<|>): (X, E) -> Eee: E> aa: V) { inline "#1" }

// Add the divergent effect to a function effect.
extern inline inject-divstd/core/inject-div: forall<a,b,e> ((a) -> e b) -> ((a) -> <div|e> b) : forall<aa: V,bb: V,ee: E> (aa: V -> ee: E bb: V) -> (astd/core/(<>): E -> <divstd/core/div: X|std/core/(<|>): (X, E) -> Eee: E> bb: V) { inline "#1" }

// Add the state effect to a function effect.
extern inline inject-ststd/core/inject-st: forall<a,b,h,e> ((a) -> e b) -> total ((a) -> <st<h>|e> b) : forall<aa: V,bb: V,hh: H,ee: E> ((aa: V) -> ee: E bb: V) -> totalstd/core/total: E ((aa: V) -> <ststd/core/st: H -> E<hh: H>|ee: E> bb: V)   { inline "#1" }

// Add the state effect to a function effect.
extern inline inject-ststd/core/inject-st: forall<a,h,e> (() -> e a) -> total (() -> <st<h>|e> a) : forall<aa: V,hh: H,ee: E> (() -> ee: E aa: V) -> totalstd/core/total: E (() -> <ststd/core/st: H -> E<hh: H>|ee: E> aa: V)  { inline "#1" }

// Exceptions
type exceptionstd/core/exception: V

type open exception-infostd/core/exception-info: V {
  Errorstd/core/Error: exception-info
  Assertstd/core/Assert: exception-info
  Todostd/core/Todo: exception-info
  Rangestd/core/Range: exception-info
  Patternstd/core/Pattern: (location : string, definition : string) -> exception-info( locationlocation: string : stringstd/core/string: V, definitiondefinition: string : stringstd/core/string: V )
  Systemstd/core/System: (errno : string) -> exception-info( errnoerrno: string : stringstd/core/string: V )   
  Internalstd/core/Internal: (name : string) -> exception-info( namename: string : stringstd/core/string: V )  
}

  cs "Primitive.ExnInfo"
  js "exn_info"
}

  js "exn_stacktrace"

  js "exn_message"

// Show the exception message and its stack trace.
fun showstd/core/show: (exn : exception) -> string( exnexn: exception : exceptionstd/core/exception: V ) : stringstd/core/string: V {
  exnexn: exception.stack-tracestd/core/stack-trace: (exn : exception) -> string
}

// Raise an exception with a specified message.
fun errorstd/core/error: forall<a> (message : string) -> exn a( messagemessage: string : stringstd/core/string: V ) : exnstd/core/exn: X aa: V { 
  throwstd/core/throw.1: forall<a> (message : string, err : ?exception-info) -> exn a(messagemessage: string,Errorstd/core/Error: exception-info)
}

// Throw an exception
fun throwstd/core/throw.1: forall<a> (message : string, err : ?exception-info) -> exn a( messagemessage: string : stringstd/core/string: V, errerr: ?exception-info : exception-infostd/core/optional: V -> V = Errorstd/core/Error: exception-info) : exnstd/core/exn: X aa: V {
  throwstd/core/throw: forall<a> (exn : exception) -> exn a( exceptionstd/core/exception: (message : string, info : exception-info) -> exception(messagemessage: string,errerr: exception-info) )
}

// Raise a pattern match exception. This is function is used internally by the
// compiler to generate error messages on pattern match failures.
extern error-patternstd/core/error-pattern: forall<a> (location : string, definition : string) -> exn a(locationlocation: string : stringstd/core/string: V, definitiondefinition: string : stringstd/core/string: V) : exnstd/core/exn: X aa: V { 
  // needs to be extern since the compiler generates calls and dependency resolution does not work on it
  cs "Primitive.ExnErrorPattern"
  js "exn_error_pattern"  
}
  
// Execute a `hndler` no matter what exception was raised in `action`.
// Use of `on-exit` is preferred (which has its arguments swapped).
extern finallystd/core/finally: forall<e,a> (action : () -> e a, hndl : () -> e ()) -> e a : forall<ee: E,aa: V> (action: () -> ee: E aa: V, hndl: () -> ee: E (std/core/(): V)std/core/(): V) -> ee: E aa: V  {
  cs inline "Primitive.Finally<##2>(#1,#2)" // todo: handle cps
  js inline "_primfinally(action,hndl, (typeof _k === 'undefined' ? undefined : _k))"
}


// Catch an exception raised by `error` and handle it.
// Use `on-exn` or `on-fail` when appropiate.
extern catchstd/core/catch: forall<e,a> (action : () -> <exn|e> a, hndl : (exception) -> e a) -> e a : forall<ee: E,aa: V> ( action : () -> <exnstd/core/exn: X|std/core/(<|>): (X, E) -> Eee: E> aa: V, hndl: exceptionstd/core/exception: V -> ee: E aa: V) -> ee: E aa: V {
  cs inline "Primitive.Catch<##2>(#1,#2)" // todo: handle cps
  js inline "_primcatch(#1, #2, (typeof _k === 'undefined' ? undefined : _k))"
}

{
  catch-on-exnstd/core/catch-on-exn: forall<e,a> (action : () -> e a, hndler : (exception) -> e a) -> e a( actionaction: () -> <exn|_21475> _21474, fun(exnexn: exception){ hndlerhndler: (exception) -> <exn|_21475> ()(exnexn: exception); throwstd/core/throw: forall<a> (exn : exception) -> exn a(exnexn: exception) })

// Transform an `:either` type back to an `exn` effect by throwing on `Left`.

    Rightstd/core/Right: forall<a,b> (right : b) -> either<a,b>(xx: _23982)  -> xx: _23982
  }
}

// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Internal types
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// Optional is used internally by the compiler to pass optional arguments.
// It is usually displayed as `:?a` for some type `:a`.
type optionalstd/core/optional: V -> V<aa: V> {
  // The `Optional` constructor is used when an optional argument is given.
  con Optionalstd/core/Optional: forall<a> (value : a) -> ?a(valuevalue: 170:aa: V)
  // `None` is used when an optional argument is not provided.
  con Nonestd/core/None: forall<a> ?a
}


// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Null is used for external interfaces 
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// Abstract type used for passing `null` values to external functions
type nullstd/core/null: V -> V<aa: V> 

// Transform a `:maybe` type to a `:null` type (using `null` for `Nothing`).
external nullstd/core/null: forall<a> (x : maybe<a>) -> null<a>(xx: maybe<_5356> : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V>) : nullstd/core/null: V -> V<aa: V> {
  cs inline "(#1==std_core._maybe<##1>.Nothing_ ? default(##1) : #1.@value)"
  js inline "(#1==null ? null : #1.value)"
}

// Transform a `:null` type to a `:maybe` type. Note that it is not
// always the case that `id(x) == maybe(null(x))` (e.g. when `x = Just(Nothing)`).
external maybestd/core/maybe: forall<a> (n : null<a>) -> maybe<a>( nn: null<_21111> : nullstd/core/null: V -> V<aa: V> ) : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V> {
  cs inline "(#1==null ? std_core._maybe<##1>.Nothing_ : new std_core._maybe<##1>(#1))"
  js inline "(#1==null ? $std_core.Nothing : $std_core.Just(#1))"
}

// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// Standard Data types
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// The `:void` type is empty and has no constructors.
// See also the `:()` unit type and the `:bool` type.
type voidstd/core/void: V

// The type of booleans has two inhabitants: `True` and `False`.
type boolstd/core/bool: V {
  con Falsestd/core/False: bool
  con Truestd/core/True: bool
}


fun intstd/core/int.3: (b : bool) -> int( bb: bool : boolstd/core/bool: V ) : intstd/core/int: V  -> if (bb: bool) then 1 else 0

fun mbintstd/core/mbint: (m : maybe<int>) -> int( mm: maybe<int> : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<intstd/core/int: V> ) : intstd/core/int: V {
  match(mm: maybe<int>) {
    Nothingstd/core/Nothing: forall<a> maybe<a> -> 0
    Juststd/core/Just: forall<a> (value : a) -> maybe<a>(ii: int) -> ii: int
  }
}

// Convert an int to a boolean, using `False` for 0 and `True` otherwise.
fun boolstd/core/bool: (i : int) -> bool( ii: int : intstd/core/int: V ) : boolstd/core/bool: V  -> (ii: int!=std/core/(!=).1: (int, int) -> bool0)

// Convert a `:maybe` type to a boolean using `False` for `Nothing` and `True` for `Just`.
fun boolstd/core/bool.1: forall<a> (m : maybe<a>) -> bool( mm: maybe<_12512> : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V> ) : boolstd/core/bool: V {
  match(mm: maybe<_12512>) {
    Nothingstd/core/Nothing: forall<a> maybe<a> -> Falsestd/core/False: bool
    _       -> Truestd/core/True: bool
  }
}

// Convert a string to a boolean, using `False` for the empty string and `True` otherwise.
fun boolstd/core/bool.2: (s : string) -> bool( ss: string : stringstd/core/string: V ) : boolstd/core/bool: V  -> (ss: string!=std/core/(!=).3: (string, string) -> bool"")

// The unit type `:()` is inhabited by just a single value, namely `()`.
// See also the `:void` type and the `:bool` type.
struct (std/core/(): V)std/core/(): V

// The `:maybe` type is used to represent either a value (`Just(x)`) or `Nothing`.
// This type is often used to represent values that can be _null_.
type maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V> {
  con Nothingstd/core/Nothing: forall<a> maybe<a>
  con Juststd/core/Just: forall<a> (value : a) -> maybe<a>( valuevalue: 162 : aa: V )
}

// Match a `:maybe` value and either return a default value on `Nothing` or apply a function to the value on `Just`
fun maybestd/core/maybe.1: forall<a,b,e> (m : maybe<a>, onNothing : b, onJust : (a) -> e b) -> e b( mm: maybe<_21122> : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V>, onNothingonNothing: _21123: bb: V, onJustonJust: (_21122) -> _21124 _21123: aa: V -> ee: E bb: V ) : ee: E bb: V
{
  match(mm: maybe<_21122>) {
    Nothingstd/core/Nothing: forall<a> maybe<a> -> onNothingonNothing: _21123
    Juststd/core/Just: forall<a> (value : a) -> maybe<a>(xx: _21122) -> onJustonJust: (_21122) -> _21124 _21123(xx: _21122)
  }
}

// Convert a `:maybe<a>` value to `:a`, using the `nothing` parameter for `Nothing`.
fun defaultstd/core/default: forall<a> (m : maybe<a>, nothing : a) -> a( mm: maybe<_5032> : maybestd/core/maybe: V -> V<aa: V>, nothingnothing: _5032 : aa: V ) : astd/core/(<>): E {

// Euclidean modulus of two integers; always a non-negative number. See also `divmod:(x : int, y : int) -> (int,int)`.
extern inline (%)std/core/(%): (int, int) -> int  : (intstd/core/int: V,intstd/core/int: V) -> intstd/core/int: V { 
  cs "Primitive.IntMod"
  js "$std_core._int_mod"

// Euclidean-0 division & modulus.
// Euclidean division is defined as: For any `D`  and `d`  where `d!=0` , we have:
//
// 1. `D == d*(D/d) + (D%d)` 
// 2. `D%d`  is always positive where `0 <= D%d < abs(d)` 
//
// Moreover, Euclidean-0 is a total function, for the case where `d==0`  we have
// that `D%0 == D`  and `D/0 == 0` . So property (1) still holds, but not property (2).
// 
// Useful laws that hold for Euclidean-0 division:
//
// * `D/(-d) == -(D/d)` 
// * `D%(-d) == D%d` 
// * `D/(2^n) == sar(D,n)         `  (with `0 <= n <= 31`  and `2^n`  means `2`  to the power of `n` )
// * `D%(2^n) == D & ((2^n) - 1)  `  (with `0 <= n <= 31`  and `2^n`  means `2`  to the power of `n` )
//
// See also _Division and modulus for computer scientists, Daan Leijen, 2001_ for further information
// available at: <http://research.microsoft.com/pubs/151917/divmodnote.pdf> .
extern inline divmodstd/core/divmod: (x : int, y : int) -> (int, int)(x:intstd/core/int: V,y:intstd/core/int: V) : (std/core/(,): (V, V) -> Vintstd/core/int: V,intstd/core/int: V)std/core/(,): (V, V) -> V { 
  cs "Primitive.IntDivMod"
  js "$std_core._int_divmod" 
}

// A `:sslice` represents a sub-slice of string and
// has a specific start position and character count. It is used
// instead of string indices to make the actual internal representation
// of strings abstract (like UTF-8 or UTF-16). String slices are 
// returned by functions that find sub strings or patterns in
// in strings. Use `string:(slice : sslice) -> string` to 
// create a fresh substring from a slice. 
abstract struct sslicestd/core/sslice: V( strstr: string : stringstd/core/string: V, startstart: int32 : int32std/core/int32: V, lenlen: int32 : int32std/core/int32: V )

// Internal export for the regex module
fun ".new-sslice"( strstr: string :stringstd/core/string: V, startstart: int32: int32std/core/int32: V, lenlen: int32 : int32std/core/int32: V ) {
  Sslicestd/core/Sslice: (str : string, start : int32, len : int32) -> sslice(strstr: string,startstart: int32,lenlen: int32)
}

  js inline "(#1 !== #2)"

  js inline "(#1===#2 ? 0 : (#1 > #2 ? 1 : -1))"

// Append two strings.

// O(`count`). Advance the start position of a string slice by `count` characters
// up to the end of the string.
// A negative `count` advances the start position backwards upto the first position
// in a string.
// Maintains the character count of the original slice upto the end of the string.
// For example:
//
// * `"abc".first.advance(1).string == "b"`,
// * `"abc".first.advance(3).string == ""`,
// * `"abc".last.advance(-1).string == "b"`.
// 
public extern advancestd/core/advance: (slice : sslice, count : int) -> sslice( sliceslice: sslice : sslicestd/core/sslice: V, countcount: int : intstd/core/int: V ) : sslicestd/core/sslice: V {
  cs "Primitive.SliceAdvance"
  js "_sslice_advance"
}

// Count occurences of `pattern` in a string.
public extern inline countstd/core/count: (s : string, pattern : string) -> int( s : stringstd/core/string: V, pattern : stringstd/core/string: V ) : intstd/core/int: V {

// Show an `:int` as a hexadecimal value.\
// The `width`  parameter specifies how wide the hex value is where `"0"`  is used to align.\
// The `use-capitals` parameter (= `True`) determines if captical letters should be used to display the hexadecimal digits.\
// The `pre` (=`"0x"`) is an optional prefix for the number (goes between the sign and the number).

// Show a `:double` as a string.
// If `d >= 1.0e-5` and `d < 1.0e+21`, `show-fixed` is used and otherwise `show-exp`.
// Default `precision` is `-17`.
fun showstd/core/show.2: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string( dd: double : doublestd/core/double: V, precisionprecision: ?int : intstd/core/optional: V -> V = -17 ) : stringstd/core/string: V {
  val dabsdabs: double = dd: double.absstd/core/abs.1: (d : double) -> double
  if (dabsstd/core/True: bool >=std/core/(>=).2: (double, double) -> bool 1.0e-5 &&std/core/(&&): (bool, bool) -> bool dabsdabs: double <std/core/(<).3: (double, double) -> bool 1.0e+21) 
   then show-fixedstd/core/show-fixed: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string(dd: double,precisionprecision: int)
   else show-expstd/core/show-exp: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string(dd: double,precisionprecision: int)
}

// Show a `:double` as a string using full precision so it can round-trip after parsing.
fun show-fullstd/core/show-full: (d : double) -> string( dd: double : doublestd/core/double: V ) : stringstd/core/string: V {
  show-expstd/core/show-exp: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string(dd: double,20)
}

// Show a `:double` fixed-point notation.
// The optional `precision` (= `-2`) specifies the maximum precision.
// If `>=0` it specifies the number of digits behind the dot (up to `20` max).
// If negative, then at most the absolute value of `precision` digits behind the dot are used.
// This may still show a number in exponential notation if the it is too small or large,
// in particular, for  a `d` where `d > 1.0e21` or `d < 1.0e-15`, or if
// `precision.abs > 17`, the `show-exp` routine is used. 
fun show-fixedstd/core/show-fixed: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string( dd: double : doublestd/core/double: V, precisionprecision: ?int : intstd/core/optional: V -> V = -2 ) : stringstd/core/string: V {
  val dabsdabs: double = dd: double.absstd/core/abs.1: (d : double) -> double
  if (dabsstd/core/True: bool <std/core/(<).3: (double, double) -> bool 1.0e-15 ||std/core/(||): (bool, bool) -> bool dabsdabs: double >std/core/(>).2: (double, double) -> bool 1.0e+21)
   then show-expstd/core/show-exp: (d : double, precision : ?int) -> string(dd: double,precisionprecision: int)
   else show-fixedxstd/core/show-fixedx: (d : double, prec : int32) -> string(dd: double, precisionprecision: int.int32std/core/int32: (int) -> int32)
}

private extern show-fixedxstd/core/show-fixedx: (d : double, prec : int32) -> string( dd: double : doublestd/core/double: V, precprec: int32 : int32std/core/int32: V ) : stringstd/core/string: V {
  cs "Primitive.DoubleShowFixed"
  js "_double_show_fixed"
}

{

    else "\\U" +std/core/(+).3: (string, string) -> string cc: char.intstd/core/int: (char) -> int.show-hexstd/core/show-hex: (i : int, width : ?int, use-capitals : ?bool, pre : ?string) -> string(6,pre="")

// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------
// References
// ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

// The predicate `:hdiv<h,a,e>` signifies that if the type `:a` contains a reference to `:h`,
// then the effect `:e` must contain the divergent effect (`:div`). This constraint is generated
// when writing to the heap (see `(!)`) and is necessary to catch cases where code can diverge
// by storing selfReferential funs in the heap.
type hdivstd/core/hdiv: (H, V, E) -> P :: (H,V,E) -> P

// A reference `:ref<h,a>` points to a value of type `:a` in heap `:h`.
type refstd/core/ref: (H, V) -> V :: (H,V) -> V

// Allocate a fresh reference with an initial value.
extern inline refstd/core/ref: forall<h,a> (value : a) -> (alloc<h>) ref<h,a> : forall<hh: H,aa: V> (value:aa: V) -> allocstd/core/alloc: H -> X<hh: H> refstd/core/ref: (H, V) -> V<hh: H,aa: V> { 
  cs inline "new Ref<##1,##2>(#1)";
  js inline "{ value: #1 }"
}

// Assign a new value to a reference.
extern inline setstd/core/set: forall<h,a> (ref : ref<h,a>, assigned : a) -> (write<h>) ()  : forall<hh: H,aa: V> (ref: refstd/core/ref: (H, V) -> V<hh: H,aa: V>, assigned: aa: V) -> <std/core/(<>): Ewritestd/core/write: H -> X<hh: H>> (std/core/(): V)std/core/(): V { 
  cs inline "#1.Set(#2)";
  js inline "((#1).value = #2)"
}

// Read the value of reference.
extern inline (!)std/core/(!): forall<h,a,e> (ref : ref<h,a>) -> <read<h>|e> a with hdiv<h,a,e> : forall<hh: H,aa: V,ee: E> (ref: refstd/core/ref: (H, V) -> V<hh: H,aa: V>) -> <readstd/core/read: H -> X<hh: H>|std/core/(<|>): (X, E) -> Eee: E> aa: V with(hdivstd/core/hdiv: (H, V, E) -> P<hh: H,aa: V,ee: E>)  { 
  cs inline "#1.Value";
  js inline "((#1).value)";
}

// If a heap effect is unobservable, the heap effect can be erased by using the `run` fun.
// See also: _State in Haskell, by Simon Peyton Jones and John Launchbury_.
